data.title: Rifle and Pistol Shooting World Competitions
data.meta_description: Rifle and Pistol Shooting World Competitions
data.text:
Rifle and pistol shooting at the Olympic Games

Since 1968, women were allowed to compete shooting alongside the men. In 1984, the program was segregated for most events except of the shotgun events.

(?) or /? means tie breaker unkown.

1. 1896, Apr 08 - 12 Athína GRE 2. 1900, Aug 01 - 05 Paris FRA 3. 1904 not competed 1906, Apr 23 - 28 Athína GRE 4. 1908, Jul 09 - 11 London GBR 5. 1912, Jun 29 - Jul 05 Stockholm SWE 6. 1916, May 28 - Jun 03 Berlin GER (canceled due to World War I) 7. 1920, Jul 29 - Aug 03 Antwerpen BEL 8. 1924, Jun 23 - 28 Paris FRA 9. 1928 not competed 10. 1932, Aug 12 - 13 Los Angeles USA 11. 1936, Aug 06 - 08 Berlin GER 12. 1940, Jul 24 - 27 Helsinki FIN (canceled due to World War II) 13. 1944 London GBR (canceled due to World War II) 14. 1948, Aug 02 - 06 London GBR 15. 1952, Jul 25 - 29 Helsinki FIN 16. 1956, Nov 30 - Dec 05 Melbourne AUS 17. 1960, Sep 03 - 10 Roma ITA 18. 1964, Oct 15 - 20 Tokyo JPN 19. 1968, Oct 18 - 23 Ciudad de México MEX 20. 1972, Aug 27 - Sep 02 München FRG 21. 1976, Jul 18 - 23 Montreal CAN 22. 1980, Jul 20 - 25 Moskva URS 23. 1984, Jul 29 - Aug 03 Los Angeles USA 24. 1988, Sep 18 - 24 Seoul KOR 25. 1992, Jul 26 - Aug 01 Barcelona ESP 26. 1996, Jul 20 - 26 Atlanta USA 27. 2000, Sep 16 - 23 Sydney AUS 28. 2004, Aug 14 - 22 Athína GRE 29. 2008, Aug 09 - 17 Beijing CHN 30. 2012, Jul 28 - Aug 06 London GBR 31. 2016, Aug 06 - 14 Rio de Janeiro BRA 32. 2021, Jul 24 - Aug 02 Tokyo JPN

2021: The IOC postponed the Olympic Games to 2021 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Shooting was originally scheduled on 2020, Jul 25 - Aug 03.

1952: The tie was decided by comparison of the shots in the inner ring (in parentheses).

1956: The tie was decided by comparison of the scores in prone position (in parentheses).

1976: The tie was decided by comparison of the last series of 10 shots (kneeling) (in parentheses).

1988 - 1996: The top 8 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round. There, they fired additional 10 shots in prone position. These shots scored in increments of 0,1, with a maximum score of 10,9. The final result is the addition of qualifying and final score.

2000 - 2012: The top 8 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round. There, they fired additional 10 shots in standing position. These shots scored in increments of 0,1, with a maximum score of 10,9. The final result is the addition of qualifying and final score.

2016: The top 8 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round without taking into account the qualification scores. There, they fired additional 3 shots kneeling, 3 shots prone and 2 shots standing. The lowest ranked two shooters are eliminated than. After every next shot in standing position the lowest ranked shooter is eliminated. All these (max. 13) final shots were in decimal scores.

Since 2016, the top 8 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round without taking into account the qualification scores. There, they fired additional 3 series of 5 shots kneeling, 3 series prone and 2 series standing. The lowest ranked two shooters are eliminated than. After every next shot in standing position the lowest ranked shooter is eliminated. All these (max. 45) final shots were in decimal scores.

2021: ROC = Russian Olympic Committee athletes at the 2020 Summer Olympics; This is the outcome of a decision by the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) on 9 December 2019 banning Russia from all international sport for four years, after it was found that data provided by the Russian Anti-Doping Agency had been manipulated by Russian authorities with a goal of protecting athletes involved in its state-sponsored doping scheme. As at the 2018 Winter Olympics, WADA would allow individual cleared Russian athletes to compete neutrally under a title to be determined (which may not include the name „Russia‟, unlike the use of „Olympic Athletes from Russia‟ in 2018).

Air rifle, 10 m - Mixed team

Gold Q1 Q2 F Silver Q1 Q2 F Bronze Q1 Q2 F 2021 YANG Qian - YANG Haoran CHN 633,2 419,7 17 TUCKER Mary - KOZENIESKY Lucas USA 628,0 418,0 13 KARIMOVA Yuliya - KAMENSKIY Sergey ROC 628,9 417,1 17

The top 8 mixed teams in the qualifying round 1 (every shooter fired 30 shots) moved on to the qualifying round 2 without taking into account the qualification scores. There, the mixed teams fired again 40 shots (every shooter 20 shots). The best two pairs qualified to the Gold medal shooting and the next two teams to the Bronze medal shooting. In the medal round after each shooter made one shot, the team with the higher score received one point (In case of a tie every team got one point). As soon as one team had reached 16 points, the „duel‟ was over. All shots were in decimal scores.

1896: Muzzle-loading pistol, 30 shots, scoring hits/points

1900: Military pistol, 6 shots, 20 m

1906: Free pistol, 30 shots

1912: Dueling pistol, 30 shots, 30 m, scoring was first by number of targets hit, and then by points; The target showed a human military person (height 1,63 m) with scoring rings (1 - 10).

1920: Military pistol, 30 shots, 30 m; The target showed a human military person (height 1,63 m) with scoring rings (1 - 10).

1924: 18 shots, only hits were scored; Every shoot-off had 6 shots where the time reduced from 18 to 8 seconds for the series. The exact results of the shoot offs are unknown except order of elimination and the gold medal shoot-off.

1932: 18 shots in 3 series of 6 shots where in each series the target visible for 8 seconds, only hits were scored; Every shoot-off had 6 shots where the time reduced from to 6 seconds for the first series, in the next series to 5 seconds, then to 4 seconds and repeated until the tie was broken.

1936: 18 shots in 3 series of 6 shots where in each series the target visible for 8 seconds, only hits were scored; Every shoot-off had 6 shots where the time reduced from to 6 seconds for the first series, in the next series to 4 seconds, then to 3 and finally 2 seconds and repeated until the tie was broken. The target showed a human silhouette (height 1,63 m).

1948 - 1956: scoring was first by number of targets hit, and then by points; ties were decided by shoot-offs of 15 shots

1960 - 1984: Ties were decided by shoot-offs of three 5-shots-series in 4 seconds each.

1988: The top 8 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round. There, they fired additional 10 shots. The final result is the addition of qualifying and final score. Ties were broken first by the total of the two series in the final.

1992: The competition format used a three-round tournament for the only time, using a qualifying round (60 shots), semifinal of 8 shooters (4 series of 5 shots in 4 seconds each), and a final of 4 shooters (10 shots). Ties were decided first by the total of the two series in the final.

1996 - 2000: The top 8 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round. There, they fired additional 10 shots. These shots scored in increments of 0,1, with a maximum score of 10,9. The final result is the addition of qualifying and final score. Ties were decided first by the total of the two series in the final.

2004: The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round. There, they fired additional 10 shots. These shots scored in increments of 0,1, with a maximum score of 10,9. The final result is the addition of qualifying and final score. Ties were decided first by the total of the two series in the final.

2008: The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round. There, they fired additional 20 shots. These shots scored in increments of 0,1, with a maximum score of 10,9. The final result is the addition of qualifying and final score.

Since 2012: The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round, qualifying scores did not carry over to the final. The final switched to a „hit-or-miss‟ system, where a 9.7 or better scores as a „hit‟ for 1 point and anything lower scores as a „miss‟ for 0 points. The final featured 8 series of 5 shots each (5 points maximum per series, 40 points maximum total). However, starting with the fourth series, the remaining shooter with the lowest total was eliminated after each series (5 shooters remaining in the fifth series, 4 in the sixth, 3 in the seventh, and only 2 in the eighth and final series).

1984: Ties were decided by shoot-offs of 20 shots.

1988 - 1992: The top 8 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round. There, they fired additional 10 shots. The final result is the addition of qualifying and final score. Ties were decided first by the total of the final.

1996 - 2004: The top 8 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round. There, they fired additional 10 shots. These shots scored in increments of 0,1, with a maximum score of 10,9. The final result is the addition of qualifying and final score. Ties were decided first by the total of the final.

2008 - 2012: The top 8 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round. There, they fired additional 20 shots. These shots scored in increments of 0,1, with a maximum score of 10,9. The final result is the addition of qualifying and final score. Ties were decided first by the total of the final.

2016: The top 8 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the semifinal, qualifying scores did not carry over to the final rounds. In the semi-finals, every competitor had five series of five shots. The sum of the target-hits scored decided about the medal games. A table was established where the first and second fought for the gold medal, while the third and fourth - for the bronze medal. In the gold and bronze medal matches the winners of each five shot series got 2 match points (in case of a tie 1 match point each). The medal match ended when the first shooter achieved 8 match points.

2021: The top 8 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round, qualifying scores did not carry over to the final. The (rapid fire shooting) final switched to a „hit-or-miss‟ system, where a 9.7 or better scores as a „hit‟ for 1 point and anything lower scores as a „miss‟ for 0 points. The final featured 10 series of 5 shots each (5 points maximum per series, 40 points maximum total). However, starting with the fourth series, the remaining shooter with the lowest total was eliminated after each series (7 shooters remaining in the fifth series, 6 in the sixth, etc.). Ties were decided by 5 shot series until the tie is broken.

Every second shot the lowest ranked shooter is eliminated beginning from shot 8. All these final shots were in decimal scores.

2021: The top 8 mixed teams in the qualifying round 1 (every shooter fired 30 shots) moved on to the qualifying round 2 without taking into account the qualification scores. There, the mixed teams fired again 40 shots (every shooter 20 shots). The best two pairs qualified to the Gold medal shooting and the next two teams to the Bronze medal shooting. In the medal round after each shooter made one shot, the team with the higher score received one point (In case of a tie no team got one point). As soon as one team had reached 16 points, the „duel„ was over.

Word Cup Finals - Rifle and pistol

The ISSF World Cup was introduced in 1986 to provide a homogeneous system for qualification to the Olympic shooting competitions. It still is carried out in the Olympic shooting events, with four competitions per year in each event. For the best shooters there is a World Cup Final since 1988 (1988 - 2004 always together with running target).

To the Finals, the following shooters are qualified:

- The defending Olympic, World, ISSF World Cup Final champions.

- Silver and Bronze medalists of either the last Olympic or the World Championship, whichever competition that was most recently held.

- The eight shooters that have made the best performances at the World Cup competitions during the year. For rating the performances, a special score system is used by taking into account of both the rank and the score achieved in the competitions.

- As many as two shooters can be nominated by the host country to compete in two of the World Cup Final events if no one from the host country qualifies.

1988: Ties were decided first by the total of the final.

1993 - 2009: The top 4 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round. There, they fired additional 10 shots. These shots scored in increments of 0,1, with a maximum score of 10,9. The final result is the addition of qualifying and final score.

2001: The tie was decided by series of 5 shots in 4 seconds until the tie was broken.

2005: The top 8 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round. There, they fired additional 20 shots. These shots scored in increments of 0,1, with a maximum score of 10,9. The final result is the addition of qualifying and final score.

Since 2010, the top 6 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round, qualifying scores did not carry over to the final. The final switched to a "hit-or-miss" system, where a 9.7 or better scores as a "hit" for 1 point and anything lower scores as a "miss" for 0 points. The final featured 8 series of 5 shots each (5 points maximum per series, 40 points maximum total). However, starting with the fourth series, the remaining shooter with the lowest total was eliminated after each series (5 shooters remaining in the fifth series, 4 in the sixth, 3 in the seventh, and only 2 in the eighth and final series).

1990: Ties were decided first by the total of the final.

2013 - 2015: The top 8 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the semifinal, qualifying scores did not carry over to the final rounds. In the semi-finals, every competitor had five series of five shots. The sum of the target-hits scored decided about the medal games. A table was established where the first and second fought for the gold medal, while the third and fourth - for the bronze medal. In the gold and bronze medal matches the winners of each five shot series got 2 match points (in case of a tie 1 match point each). The medal match ended when the first shooter achieved 7 match points. The gap between the match points of both shooters has to be 2 at minimum. If not the medal shooting will prolong.

Since 2016: The top 8 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round, qualifying scores did not carry over to the final. The (rapid fire shooting) final switched to a „hit-or-miss‟ system, where a 9.7 or better scores as a „hit‟ for 1 point and anything lower scores as a „miss‟ for 0 points. The final featured 10 series of 5 shots each (5 points maximum per series, 40 points maximum total). However, starting with the fourth series, the remaining shooter with the lowest total was eliminated after each series (7 shooters remaining in the fifth series, 6 in the sixth, etc.). Ties were decided by 5 shot series until the tie is broken.

In the qualifying round 2, every pair had 40 shots again. The first and second ranked pair fought for the gold medal, while the third and fourth - for the bronze medal. In the gold and bronze medal matches each team member had a single shot in each round. The first pair to reach 16 points or more will be declared the winner of the match. If there is a tie of both teams having 16 match points, the match will prolong with additional rounds until the tie is broken. All shots were in decimal scores.

1992: Ties were decided first by the total of the final.

2005: Ties were decided by a single shot shoot-off.

2013 - 2016: The top 8 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round without taking into account the qualification scores. There, they fired additional (max. 20) shots. Every second shot the lowest ranked shooter is eliminated beginning from shot 8. All these final shots were in decimal scores.

2017: The top 8 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round without taking into account the qualification scores. There, they fired additional (max. 24) shots. Every second shot the lowest ranked shooter is eliminated beginning from shot 14. All these final shots were in decimal scores.
